title: Viola Hashe
text:
Viola Hashe (1926-1977) was a teacher, anti-<a href="apartheid">apartheid</a> activist and <a href="Trade%20union">trade unionist</a> in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>. Hashe was also <a href="Visual%20impairment">blind</a>. 
Biography.
Hashe was born in 1926 in the <a href="Orange%20Free%20State%20%28province%29">Orange Free State</a>. She started working with the trade unions and joined the <a href="African%20National%20Congress">African National Congress</a> (ANC) in the 1950s. She became a member of the <a href="South%20African%20Congress%20of%20Trade%20Unions">South African Congress of Trade Unions</a> (SACTU) in the mid-1950s. In 1956, she worked on the <a href="South%20African%20Clothing%20Workers%20Union">South African Clothing Workers Union</a> (SACWU) where she became the first woman leader of an all-male South African union. Hashe spoke at the SACTU conference in <a href="Durban">Durban</a> where she discussed passes for women, since women weren't allowed to hold passes.
Hashe became the first woman to be threatened with deportation under the <a href="Pass%20laws">Urban Areas Act</a> in 1956. She had the counsel of <a href="Shulamith%20Muller">Shulamith Muller</a>, and the order to deport her was rescinded "barely seven hours before the order was to take effect." In 1963, Hashe was banned under the <a href="Suppression%20of%20Communism%20Act%2C%201950">Suppression of Communism Act, 1950</a> and then "restricted to <a href="Roodepoort">Roodepoort</a>" until her death in 1977.
Hashe influenced many people who became activists or who were already working as activists. These included <a href="Bertha%20Gxowa">Bertha Gxowa</a>, <a href="Mabel%20Balfour">Mabel Balfour</a>, and <a href="Mary%20Moodley">Mary Moodley</a>. A branch of the <a href="African%20National%20Congress">African National Congress</a> Youth League is named after Hashe.
